claim: The accounting sector of a company can promote environmental conservation through environmental costs, and at the same time, improve performance when implementing a Corporate Sustainability Management System (CSMS).
Allocating appropriate environmental costs through CSMS can effectively improve the company’s financial performance.
A proper application of CSMS, with the disclosure of environmental activities and costs, can enhance customer loyalty.
From the employees’ perspective, green product psychological ownership affects their behavior and performance.
It is important to establish a solid Green Shared Vision to avoid green confusion and improve employees’ economic performance.
There is a need for companies to build supply chain management processes that consider adequate criteria to achieve corporate sustainability.
A sum of practices, such as long-term orientation, gradual expansion, risk management, employee priority, and innovation, leads to an improvement in corporate sustainability performance.

Practices related to encouraging environmental innovation, redesigning consumers’ offer, raising support for institutions and policy measures, and organizing synergetic involvement among stakeholders can improve the corporate sustainability performance of a company.
Ownership concentration, companies from environmentally risky sectors, profitability, the firm’s size, growth opportunities, and debt are determinants for corporate sustainability performance.

Using indicators from the global reporting initiative (GRI) for corporate sustainability disclosure of firms is proposed, but there are challenges because firms in different countries may have a different understanding of corporate sustainability compared to international guidelines.
Evaluating corporate sustainability by separating indicators into four groups: social sustainability, environmental sustainability, green products, and services is relevant.

More categories are needed in order to value specific aspects of the firms, such as social sustainability, and nine categories are proposed: Corporate Governance, Product Responsibility, Transparency and Communication, Economic, Environmental, Social, Natural Environment and Climate Vulnerability, Energy Consumption, and Pandemic COVID-19 impact.
Different perspectives on sustainability by managers can influence decision-making, and a diverse team setting is recommended.
To achieve expected corporate sustainability standards, it is important to explore how management can contribute to creating value for businesses, society, and nature.
Corporate sustainability is closely related to business strategy and the development of specific organizational capabilities.
There is a gap between policy and implementation regarding corporate sustainability, and adequate policymaking is closely related to several business approaches.
The role of management accounting on corporate sustainability is important, but there are challenges with regard to extending sustainable management accounting beyond organizational barriers.

Environmental and cognitive factors create tensions to adopt sustainable solutions, proactive strategies are more effective in sustainable goals, and strategies to manage corporate sustainability paradoxes deal with complex business scenarios.
Prior meta-analyses indicate that board independence, board gender diversity, and board size have a positive impact on CSR performance.
Both CSR performance and environmental performance increase financial performance.
There are several indications for a positive significant impact of CSR performance on financial performance.
Environmental performance leads to better financial performance.
The financial performance of ESG investing has on average been indistinguishable from conventional investing.
references: Kim, C.-S., 2019. Can Socially Responsible Investments Be Compatible with Financial Performance? A Meta-analysis. Asia-Pac. J. Financ. Stud. 48, 30–64.
Revelli, C., Viviani, J.-L., 2015. Financial Performance of Socially Responsible Investing (SRI): What Have We Learned? A Meta-analysis. Bus. Ethics Eur. Rev. 24, 158–185.

claim: There exists a robust and positive association between sustainability and financial performance on the firm level.
references: Busch, T., Friede, G., 2018. The Robustness of the Corporate Social and Financial Performance Relation: A Second-Order Meta-Analysis. Corp. Soc. Responsib. Environ. Manag. 25, 583–608.

claim: The adoption of Generative AI models significantly influences companies by automating processes, leading to increased efficiency and improved resource utilization.
Another study by McKinsey (QuantumBlack) on the adoption of GAI reveals that already one-third of organizations are implementing GAI use cases in at least one function.
Generating Insights – GAI introduces new use cases for leveraging data to identify trends, analyse performance and to understand and enhance sales.
GAI can create various content types which can be used for marketing purposes like text, video, audio and images.
GAI can automate content production and reduces the need for extensive human involvement, resulting in both faster production rates and reduced marginal production costs.
Yet, McAfee et al. (2023) stresses that companies are presently cautious regarding IP right violations associated with GAI applications, choosing to wait for initial court decisions.
Virtual agents, typically in the form of chatbots, represent the most frequently observed use case in the selected literature.
GAI chatbots are more efficient, constantly polite and patient, available 24/7, are able to provide personalized answers and can significantly reduce labour costs.

GAI chatbots have a multitude of positive effects on the customer: increased service quality, enhanced customer satisfaction, increased customer retention and engagement, ability to communicate in multiple languages and an overall improved customer experience.
GAI enables real one-to-one personalization, aligning with the trend of hyper personalization.

Specific use cases could be personalized travel recommendations during the booking process based on travel history and real-time parameters such as weather, or personal financial advice based on monetary data.
GAI algorithms demonstrate the capability to optimize transport routes by assessing and integrating real-time data, such as weather conditions, traffic data and fuel prices.
GAI can optimize the warehouse inventory by leveraging advanced real-time forecasting models, which enable more accurate demand predictions and therefore optimized inventory levels.

Richey et al. (2023) also adds that, with the capability to continuously monitor and forecast demands, GAI could autonomously manage stocks by following flexible inventory level policies and thereby facilitate lean, just-in-time warehouse operations.
The deployment of GAI allows for the generation of an optimal warehouse layout.
The ability of GAI to combine and assess massive amounts of unstructured and structured data from various sources can be used for quality management.
This results in fewer manual inspections being required, leading to an increase in product or manufacturing quality and enabling companies to save money.
GAI can improve the supply chain collaboration and transparency between businesses and their suppliers.
GAI can also be employed to initiate automated communication with suppliers, providing early notice in the event of future demand spikes and securing possible capacities.

The capability to combine various datasets enables GAI to continually analyse supplier portfolios based on factors such as product quality, reliability, efficiency, insolvency risks and sustainability.
GAI can then suggest supplier changes.
GAI could also suggest or automize contract clauses and price negotiation tactics based on supplier data and behaviour.
GAI can be used to generate code from natural language.
GAI is being utilized for auto-completing code.
GAI has the capability to translate legacy code into modern programming languages.
With these three use cases, software development becomes much faster and more cost-effective.
The development of new code with GAI is 30-50% faster and code refactoring 20-30% faster.
Software engineers need to be kept in the loop to mitigate the risk of implementing bugs and security gaps.
GAI can undertake various tasks in software development.
GAI can automate the software testing procedure by generating and simulating test scenarios for the requirements.
GAI can generate recommendations or ideas for software requirements and features, while also predicting features that may arise in the future.
GAI can handle simple inquiries, e.g. password resets or basic diagnostics, develop standard operating procedures and generate IT performance reports.
Using GAI to generate synthetic datasets enhances overall data sample size and variability without sacrificing privacy protection.
A further use case would be the simulation of stress tests and disruptive scenarios or creating synthetic fraudulent transactions to train security algorithms in finance.
GAI can generate valuable insights within the finance domain.
GAI-supported data analysis makes it easier to process real-time data, allowing for quicker and more information-based decision-making.
It allows to improve financial forecasting to predict market trends, currencies or stock prices through analyzing external sources such as income reports or newspaper articles.
The possibility to automate trading with GAI, to directly use emerging market situations.
The literature frequently discusses the use case of identifying fraudulent transactions in finance systems with GAI.
By analysing patterns and anomalies in finance transactions, GAI is capable of identifying and highlighting fraudulent activities.
This can reduce the risk and impact of financial crime and can save costs for human labour.
GAI can be used in the product development department to generate new product ideas.
GAI’s innovation capability, highlighting that brainstorming with GAI can generate significantly more ideas.
GAI can also conduct market research and identify gaps and potential innovations.
Organizations could thus develop product innovations faster and respond faster to market trends.
Simultaneously, the innovations process becomes more cost efficient and accessible for organizations without a dedicated research department.
The sole reliance in GAI as innovator can potentially hinder ground-breaking innovations, as GAI still relies on training patterns and data.
GAI can also take on product design tasks.
GAI product design can be used across industries, enabling faster and more cost-efficient development.
GAI can automatically generate job descriptions, create skill requirements, prepare interview questions and help with the assessment of potential candidates.
Leveraging GAIs natural language processing (NLP) capabilities, enhances the precision of CV assessments and automatic suggestions of candidates can be generated for the recruiter.
Reverse recruiting can be improved with GAI through more personalized job recommendations on platforms such as LinkedIn.
The use of GAI in recruitment can lead to discrimination and inequality through biased models.
GAI can be used as a digital agent in HR, similar to marketing service agents or field service agents, to give human like responses to queries.
A Digital HR agent handles tasks, which would usually be handled by HR service centers like managing personal data or queries on pay slips.
GAI can also provide answers to improve employee wellbeing, create HR documents and assists line manager with leadership skills and performance assessments.
The use of GAI enables HR employees to focus on more core and strategic HR tasks.
